text: And Isaac answered and said unto Esau, Behold, I have made him thy lord, and all his brethren have I given to him for servants; and with corn and wine have I sustained him: and what shall I do now unto thee, my son?
text_kjv: And Isaac answered and said unto Esau, Behold, I have made him thy lord, and all his brethren have I given to him for servants; and with corn and wine have I sustained him: and what shall I do now unto thee, my son?
text_niv: Isaac answered Esau, “I have made him lord over you and have made all his relatives his servants, and I have sustained him with grain and new wine. So what can I possibly do for you, my son?”
text_esv: Isaac answered and said to Esau, “Behold, I have made him lord over you, and all his brothers I have given to him for servants, and with grain and wine I have sustained him. What then can I do for you, my son?”
text_nlt: Isaac said to Esau, “I have made Jacob your master and have declared that all his brothers will be his servants. I have guaranteed him an abundance of grain and wine — what is left for me to give you, my son?”
text_msg: Isaac answered Esau, "I've made him your master, and all his brothers his servants, and lavished grain and wine on him. I've given it all away. What's left for you, my son?"
text_nasb: But Isaac replied to Esau, 'Behold, I have made him your master, and all his relatives I have given to him as servants; and with grain and new wine I have sustained him. Now as for you then, what can I do, my son?'
context: Genesis 27 takes place within a patriarchal and agrarian society where birthright and blessing were paramount. Isaac, nearing death and nearly blind, intended to bestow the irrevocable patriarchal blessing upon Esau, his elder son. This blessing signified not only material prosperity but also leadership and dominion within the family and tribe. The concept of primogeniture dictated that the eldest son inherited the majority of the father's possessions and assumed the role of family head. Rebekah, favoring Jacob, overheard Isaac's instructions and devised a plan to deceive Isaac and secure the blessing for Jacob. This involved Jacob impersonating Esau, using animal skins to mimic Esau's hairy arms, and presenting a savory dish prepared by Rebekah to fool Isaac's senses. The intentional deceit highlights the high stakes involved, emphasizing the perceived power and finality of Isaac's blessing. Isaac's physical frailty and failing eyesight made him vulnerable to manipulation. The passage reflects societal values that prioritized the spoken word and solemn pronouncements, viewing them as legally and spiritually binding. The consequences of such pronouncements shaped the future trajectory of the family and their descendants. Land ownership, livestock, and control over agricultural produce (corn and wine) were indicators of wealth and power in that era. The act of serving others was a clear sign of subservience and social hierarchy.
meaning: Isaac's words in Genesis 27:37 reveal the irreversible nature of the patriarchal blessing once spoken. He acknowledges that he has already conferred the blessing upon Jacob, establishing him as Esau's lord and granting him dominion over his brothers. The phrase "with corn and wine have I sustained him" suggests that Isaac's blessing involved not only future prosperity but also the assurance of abundance and sustenance. Isaac's despairing question, "what shall I do now unto thee, my son?" underscores the finality of the situation. He recognizes his power to bless is finite, having already exhausted it on Jacob. The passage highlights the themes of divine sovereignty and human choice. While Rebekah and Jacob orchestrated the deception, the narrative subtly suggests that God may have been working through their actions to fulfill a predetermined plan. This resonates with later biblical accounts where deception or morally questionable actions are used to achieve God's purposes. The blessing's focus on dominion and servitude foreshadows the future relationship between the descendants of Jacob (Israel) and Esau (Edom). Isaac's inability to retract or alter the blessing signifies the weightiness of words and the potential consequences of deceit. The blessing isn't merely a wish; it's a pronouncement that shapes reality within the narrative's framework.
application: Genesis 27:37 offers several practical applications for modern life. Firstly, it underscores the importance of integrity and honesty in our dealings with others. Jacob's deception, while ultimately fulfilling a perceived divine purpose, created lasting conflict and division within his family. We should strive for ethical conduct and avoid manipulating others to achieve our goals. Secondly, the passage highlights the power of words and the need to speak life-giving blessings over others. While we may not possess the same patriarchal authority as Isaac, our words can significantly impact the lives of those around us. We should use our words to encourage, uplift, and affirm others, rather than tearing them down. Thirdly, the story of Jacob and Esau reminds us that God's plans may unfold in unexpected ways. Even when human actions are flawed or misguided, God can still work to bring about His purposes. We should trust in God's sovereignty and be open to His guidance, even when the path ahead seems uncertain. Fourthly, Isaac's inability to undo the blessing serves as a cautionary tale against making hasty or ill-considered decisions. We should carefully consider the consequences of our choices before acting, especially when those choices involve important commitments or relationships. Finally, the verse challenges us to examine our own hearts and motivations. Are we driven by selfish ambition, or are we seeking to honor God and serve others? We should strive to align our desires with God's will and seek His guidance in all that we do.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the lessons we learn from the story of Jacob and Esau. Forgive us for the times we have been dishonest or manipulative in our dealings with others. Help us to speak words of life and encouragement, and to be mindful of the power of our words. Grant us discernment to make wise decisions and to trust in your sovereign plan, even when we don't understand it. Lord, we acknowledge your ultimate control and your ability to use even our mistakes for your glory. Help us to align our hearts with your will, and to seek your guidance in all that we do. We commit to living a life that is pleasing to you, marked by integrity, honesty, and love for others. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: The Bible states that Rebekah loved Jacob (Genesis 25:28), while Isaac loved Esau. Some speculate this preference arose from God's revelation to Rebekah before the twins' birth that the elder would serve the younger (Genesis 25:23), influencing her partiality towards Jacob, seeing him as the chosen one for God's purposes.
faqs.question: Q1: Why did Rebekah favor Jacob over Esau?

faqs.answer: No, Jacob's deception, while perhaps aligning with God's preordained outcome, was not justified. The ends do not justify the means. He should have trusted in God's plan without resorting to dishonesty. Deception is consistently condemned in Scripture, regardless of perceived good intentions.
faqs.question: Q2: Was Jacob's deception justified since God intended him to inherit the blessing?

faqs.answer: "Corn and wine" represent agricultural prosperity and abundance. They were staple foods in that culture, signifying God's provision and blessing upon the land and its inhabitants. The blessing suggests a life of sustenance and plenty for Jacob and his descendants.
faqs.question: Q3: What does the "corn and wine" mentioned in the blessing symbolize?

faqs.answer: This story highlights the tension between free will and predestination. While God may have known or even ordained that Jacob would receive the blessing, Rebekah and Jacob still chose to deceive Isaac. This complex interplay demonstrates that human choices and divine sovereignty can coexist.
faqs.question: Q4: How does this story relate to the concept of free will versus predestination?

faqs.answer: Jacob's deception resulted in a strained relationship with Esau, forcing him to flee for his life. It also established a pattern of deceit and manipulation within his family, evident in later events involving his sons. This led to years of separation and eventual reconciliation with Esau.
